title: weights and measures
comment: The peoples of the ancient Near East used a variety of standards of weights and measures, so that modern equivalents can only be approximate. The focus of Scripture is on the importance of keeping just weights and measures, and the prophets denounced those who used false balances and deceitful measures.

children.title: weights and measures, laws concerning
children.comment: God expects his people to use accurate weights and measures, and to use just balances. This is underlined in the Law, the Prophets and the wisdom literature.

children.title: The law demanded honesty in using weights and measures

primaryrefs.comment: Cheating by falsifying weights and measures was common in a culture where there was no standardisation or regulatory authority.

children.title: weights and measures, weights
children.comment: Ancient weights were usually made of stone or metal, often inscribed with their weight and standard, the shekel being the basic weight of all Semitic nations. Weights of gold and silver served as currency, since coinage was not invented until the seventh century B.C. Weights are given in ascending order, with their approximate imperial and metric equivalents.

primaryrefs.comment: The Hebrew word translated ``two thirds of a shekel'' is ``pim'', its only mention in Scripture.

primaryrefs.comment: The phrase ``the weight current among the merchants'' reflects the local variation in standards.
The royal shekel, also known in Babylonia, was slightly heavier (at about 13 grams) than the standard shekel and reflects David's attempts to bring some standardisation to this weight.

The sanctuary shekel was more precisely regulated than the common shekel, weighing exactly 20 gerahs. The common shekel may have weighed slightly less as a result of greater handling and wider circulation.
Although the mina is valued here at 60 shekels, there is some evidence that in the pre-exilic period it was valued at 50 shekels.

seealsos.comment: By NT times the mina had become coinage rather than simply a weight of silver, and was worth about three months' wages.

children.title: Talent (3,000 shekels, 60 minas): about 75 pounds (about 34 kilograms)

seealsos.comment: By NT times the talent had become coinage, and ten thousand talents would have been the equivalent of millions of pounds sterling

secondaryrefs.comment: The price in the original Hebrew is ``one hundred kesitahs'', a unit of unknown weight and value.

children.title: weights and measures, dry
children.comment: These terms derive originally from the containers used, which held a fixed amount. Measures are given in ascending order, with their approximate imperial and metric equivalents.

primaryrefs.comment: This is the only mention in Scripture of this measure.
This incident records the only mention in Scripture of this measure.
The seah was a measure used for flour and cereals.
The ephah was used only for flour and cereals, and had subdivisions of 1/6 and 1/10.

seealsos.comment: The word for ``measuring basket'' in the Hebrew is ``ephah''.

children.title: Lethek (5 ephahs or 1/2 homer): about 3 bushels (about 110 litres)

primaryrefs.comment: Possibly a Phoenician measure, this is the only mention in Scripture of this measure.
The cor was used for measuring flour and cereals, and also appears to have been used for measuring oil.

The homer is an older word than the cor, but is equivalent to it. It originally meant ``a donkey load'' and was widely used throughout the ancient Near East from the second millennium B.C. as a measure for cereals.

children.title: Other dry measures found in the NT

secondaryrefs.comment: The word translated ``quart'' is ``choinix'', a Greek measure.
The ``large amount'' referred to is ``three sata'' in the Greek.
The word translated ``bowl'' is the Roman measure ``modius''.
The measure translated as ``a thousand bushels'' is ``one hundred korous'' in the Greek.

children.title: weights and measures, liquid
children.comment: These terms derive originally from the containers used, which held a fixed amount. There is some uncertainty about the capacity of the bath, and therefore of other liquid measures dependent upon it. Measures are given in ascending order, with their approximate imperial and metric equivalents.

primaryrefs.comment: This is the only mention in Scripture of the log, as a measure of oil used in the ritual for cleansing infectious skin diseases.
The hin was used as a measure of oil, wine and water.
The bath was the equivalent liquid measure of the ephah, and was used to measure oil, wine and water.

seealsos.comment: The measure translated as ``eight hundred gallons'' is ``one hundred batous'' in the original (``batos'' being the Greek form of the Hebrew ``bath'')
The measure translated as ``twenty to thirty gallons'' is ``two to three metretas'' in the original, a Greek measure roughly equivalent to the bath.

children.title: weights and measures, linear
children.comment: These terms were based on natural units of measurement that could be easily applied. Measures are given in ascending order, with their approximate imperial and metric equivalents.

primaryrefs.comment: The finger was 1/4 handbreadth and was the smallest subdivision of the cubit. This is its only mention in Scripture.
The handbreadth was the width of the hand at the base of the four fingers.

seealsos.comment: The handbreadth is here used figuratively of the shortness of human life

children.title: Span (half a cubit): about 9 inches (about 23 centimetres)

primaryrefs.comment: The span was the width of the outstretched hand from thumb to little finger.

seealsos.comment: Goliath's height is given in the Hebrew as ``six cubits and a span''
The span is here used figuratively of the shortness of human life

primaryrefs.comment: The cubit was the distance from the fingertip to the elbow, and was used to measure height, size, depth and distance.

seealsos.comment: The Hebrew describes the depth of the water as ``fifteen cubits''
The Hebrew describes the man as ``five cubits tall''
The Greek text describes the distance as ``about two hundred cubits''

primaryrefs.comment: Originally a measuring instrument, the reed became a recognised measure of six cubits (the rod).
The Greek word for ``mile'' here is ``milion'', a transliteration of the Roman measurement ``mille passuum'', ``a thousand paces''.

seealsos.comment: The measurement in the Greek is ``sixty stadia''. Eight stadia were about one mile (about 1480 metres)
The measurement in the Greek is ``twenty-five or thirty stadia''
The measurement in the Greek is ``fifteen stadia''.

children.title: weights and measures, distance and area
children.comment: Diverse expressions were used for these measurements, their being determined in the most practical way possible, reckoned by known averages.

primaryrefs.comment: A variety of distance often lies behind this expression, as can be seen in the examples that follow.

While this is the only mention of this phrase in Scripture, it was in fact a popular expression, indicating the distance a devout Jew could walk on the Sabbath. It was based on the rabbinical interpretation of Ex 16:29 in the light of Nu 35:5, and was limited to 2,000 cubits.
The area translated ``about half an acre'' in the Hebrew means ``half a yoke''. The yoke was the area of land ploughed by a yoke of oxen in one day, approximately one acre.

seealsos.comment: The Hebrew describes the area as ``ten-yoke'', that is, the land ploughed by ten yoke of oxen in one day.
